attributes.name: Body
attributes.description:
Renders a <tbody> element and yields the row component, row data and index.

<table.body as |body person index|>
  <body.row as |row|>
    <row.cell>
      {{person.firstName}} #{{index}}
    </row.cell>
    <row.cell>
      {{person.lastName}}
    </row.cell>
    <row.cell>
      {{person.points}}
    </row.cell>
  </body.row>
</table.body>

It can also be used as a blockless component to let yeti table automatically unroll thee rows for you, based on the @prop arguments you passed in to the column definition components.

<table.body/>

Remember that this component's block will be rendered once per each item in the @data array.

fields.name: onRowClick
fields.description: Adds a click action to each row, called with the clicked row's data as an argument. Can be used with both the blockless and block invocations.

yields.name: body.row
yields.description: the row component

yields.name: rowData
yields.description: one item in the data array

attributes.name: YetiTable
attributes.description:
The primary Yeti Table component. This component represents the root of the table, and manages high level state of all of its subcomponents.

<YetiTable @data={{this.data}} as |table|>

  <table.header as |header|>
    <header.column @prop="firstName">
      First name
    </header.column>
    <header.column @prop="lastName">
      Last name
    </header.column>
    <header.column @prop="points">
      Points
    </header.column>
  </table.header>

  <table.body/>

</YetiTable>
<YetiTable @data={{this.data}} as |table|>

  <table.thead as |thead|>
    <thead.row as |row|>
      <row.column @prop="firstName">
        First name
      </row.column>
      <row.column @prop="lastName">
        Last name
      </row.column>
      <row.column @prop="points">
        Points
      </row.column>
    </thead.row>
  </table.thead>

  <table.body/>

</YetiTable>

fields.name: theme
fields.description: An object that contains classes for yeti table to apply when rendering its various table html elements. The theme object your pass in will be deeply merged with yeti-table's default theme and with a theme defined in your environment.js at ENV['ember-yeti-table'].theme.

fields.name: data
fields.description: The data for Yeti Table to render. It can be an array or a promise that resolves with an array. The only case when @data is optional is if a @loadData was passed in.

fields.name: loadData
fields.description:
The function that will be called when Yeti Table needs data. This argument is used when you don't have all the data available or loading all rows at once isn't possible, e.g the dataset is too large.

By passing in a function to @loadData you assume the responsibility to filter, sort and paginate the data (if said features are enabled).

This function must return an array or a promise that resolves with an array.

This function will be called with an argument with the current state of the table. Use this object to know what data to fetch, pass it to the server, etc. Please check the "Async Data" guide to understand what that object contains and an example of its usage.

fields.name: pagination
fields.description: Use this argument to enable the pagination feature. Default is false.

fields.name: pageSize
fields.description: Controls the size of each page. Default is 15.

fields.name: pageNumber
fields.description: Controls the current page to show. Default is 1.

fields.name: totalRows
fields.description: Optional argument that informs yeti table of how many rows your data has. Only needed when using a @loadData function and @pagination={{true}}. When you use @data, Yeti Table uses the size of that array. This information is used to calculate the pagination information that is yielded and passed to the @loadData function.

fields.name: filter
fields.description: The global filter. If passed in, Yeti Table will search all the rows that contain this string and show them. Defaults to ''.

fields.name: filterFunction
fields.description:
An optional function to customize the filtering logic. This function should return true or false to either include or exclude the row on the resulting set. If this function depends on a value, pass that value as the @filterUsing argument.

This function will be called with two arguments:

  • row - the current data row to use for filtering
  • filterUsing - the value you passed in as @filterUsing

fields.name: filterUsing
fields.description: If you @filterFunction function depends on a different value (other that @filter) to show, pass it in this argument. Yeti Table uses this argument to know when to recalculate the fitlered rows.

fields.name: sortable
fields.description: Used to enable/disable sorting on all columns. You should use this to avoid passing the @sortable argument to all columns.

fields.name: sortFunction
fields.description: Use the @sortFunction if you want to completely customize how the row sorting is done. It will be invoked with two rows, the current sortings that are applied and the @compareFunction.

fields.name: compareFunction
fields.description: Use @compareFunction if you just want to customize how two values relate to each other (not the entire row). It will be invoked with two values and you just need to return -1, 0 or 1 depending on if first value is greater than the second or not. The default compare function used is the compare function from @ember/utils.

fields.name: sortSequence
fields.description: Use @sortSequence to customize the sequence in which the sorting order will cycle when clicking on the table headers. You can either pass in a comma-separated string or an array of strings. Accepted values are 'asc', 'desc' and 'unsorted'. The default value is ['asc', 'desc'].

fields.name: ignoreDataChanges
fields.description:
Use @ignoreDataChanges to prevent yeti table from observing changes to the underlying data and resorting or refiltering. Useful when doing inline editing in a table.

Defaults to false

This is an initial render only value. Changing it after the table has been rendered will not be respected.

fields.name: renderTableElement
fields.description:
Use @renderTableElement to prevent yeti table from rendering the topmost element. Might be useful for styling purposes (e.g if you want to place your pagination controls outside of your table element). If you set this to false, you should render the table element yourself using the yielded <t.table> component.

Defaults to true

yields.name: table.header
yields.description: the table header component (Single row in header)

yields.name: table.thead
yields.description: the table header component (Allows multiple rows in header)

yields.name: table.body
yields.description: the table body component

yields.name: table.foot
yields.description: the table footer component

yields.name: table.pagination
yields.description: the pagination controls component

yields.name: table.actions
yields.description: an object that contains actions to interact with the table

yields.name: table.paginationData
yields.description: object that represents the current pagination state

yields.name: table.isLoading
yields.description: boolean that is `true` when data is being loaded

yields.name: table.columns
yields.description: the columns on the table

yields.name: table.visibleColumns
yields.description: the visible columns on the table

yields.name: table.rows
yields.description: an array of all the rows yeti table knows of. In the sync case, it will contain the entire dataset. In the async case, it will be the same as `table.visibleRows`

yields.name: table.totalRows
yields.description: the total number of rows on the table (regardless of pagination). Important argument in the async case to inform yeti table of the total number of rows in the dataset.

yields.name: table.visibleRows
yields.description: the rendered rows on the table account for pagination, filtering, etc; when pagination is false, it will be the same length as totalRows

yields.name: table.theme
yields.description: the theme being used

attributes.name: Header
attributes.description:
Renders a <thead> element and yields the column component.

<table.header as |header|>
  <header.column @prop="firstName">
    First name
  </header.column>
  <header.column @prop="lastName">
    Last name
  </header.column>
  <header.column @prop="points">
    Points
  </header.column>
</table.header>

yields.name: header.column
yields.description: the column component

attributes.name: Pagination
attributes.description:
Simple pagination controls component that is included to help you get started quickly. Yeti Table yields a lot of pagination data, so you shouldn't have a problem creating your own pagination controls.

At any rate, this component tries to be as flexible as possible. Some arguments are provided to customize how this component behaves.

If you want to render these controls on the table footer, you probably want a footer row that always spans all rows. To do that you can use a colspan equal to the yielded visibleColumns.length number. Example:

<YetiTable @data={{this.data}} @pagination={{true}} as |table|>
  ...
  <table.foot as |foot|>
    <foot.row as |row|>
      <row.cell colspan={{table.visibleColumns.length}}>
        <table.pagination/>
      </row.cell>
    </foot.row>
  </table.foot>
</YetiTable>

fields.name: pageSizes
fields.description: Array of page sizes to populate the page size <select>. Particularly useful with an array helper, e.g @pageSizes={{array 10 12 23 50 100}} Defaults to [10, 15, 20, 25].

fields.name: showInfo
fields.description: Used to show/hide some textual information about the current page. Defaults to true.

fields.name: showPageSizeSelector
fields.description: Used to show/hide the page size selector. Defaults to true.

fields.name: showButtons
fields.description: Used to show/hide the previous and next page buttons. Defaults to true.

attributes.name: Table
attributes.description:
A simple component that just renders the <table> element with the correct theme classes.

This component should only be needed when using @renderTableElement={{false}} to render the table element yourself. Please refer to the @renderTableElement documentation for more information.

Example:

<YetiTable @data={{this.data}} @pagination={{true}} @renderTableElement={{false}} as |t|>

  <t.table> {{!-- we render the given table component ourselves --}}
    <t.header as |header|>
      ...
    </t.header>

    <t.body/>
  </t.table>

  <t.pagination/> {{!-- pagination controls outside the <table> element --}}

</YetiTable>

attributes.name: TBody
attributes.description:
Renders a <tbody> element and yields the row component and data. You must iterate each row

<table.tbody as |body data|>
  {{#each data as |person index|}}
    <body.row as |row|>
      <row.cell>
        {{person.firstName}} #{{index}}
      </row.cell>
      <row.cell>
        {{person.lastName}}
      </row.cell>
      <row.cell>
        {{person.points}}
      </row.cell>
    </body.row>
  {{/each}}
</table.tbody>

Remember that you must perform the {{#each}} to iterate over the @data array.

his component does not provide a blockless variation

fields.name: onRowClick
fields.description: Adds a click action to each row, called with the clicked row's data as an argument. Can be used with both the blockless and block invocations.

yields.name: body.row
yields.description: the row component

attributes.name: TBodyCell
attributes.description:
Renders a <td> element (if its corresponding column definition has @visible={{true}}).

<row.cell>
  {{person.firstName}}
</row.cell>

fields.name: visible
fields.description: Controls the visibility of the current cell. Keep in mind that this property won't just hide the column using css. The DOM for the column will be removed. Defaults to the visible argument of the corresponding column.

attributes.name: TBodyRow
attributes.description:
Renders a <tr> element and yields the cell component.

<body.row as |row|>
  <row.cell>
    {{person.firstName}} #{{index}}
  </row.cell>
  <row.cell>
    {{person.lastName}}
  </row.cell>
  <row.cell>
    {{person.points}}
  </row.cell>
</body.row>

Remember you can cutomize each <tr> class or @onClick handler based on the row data because you have access to it from the body component.

<table.body as |body person|>
  <body.row class={{if person.isInvalid "error"}} as |row|>
    <row.cell>
      {{person.firstName}}
    </row.cell>
    <row.cell>
      {{person.lastName}}
    </row.cell>
    <row.cell>
      {{person.points}}
    </row.cell>
  </body.row>
</table.body>

fields.name: onClick
fields.description: Adds a click action to the row.

yields.name: row.cell
yields.description: the cell component

attributes.name: TFoot
attributes.description:
Renders a <tfoot> element and yields the row component.

<table.tfoot as |foot|>
  <foot.row as |row|>
    <row.cell>
      Footer content
    </row.cell>
  </foot.row>
</table.tfoot>

attributes.name: TFootCell
attributes.description:
Renders a <td> element and yields for the developer to supply content.

<table.tfoot as |foot|>
  <foot.row as |row|>
    <row.cell>
      Footer content
    </row.cell>
  </foot.row>
</table.tfoot>

fields.name: visible
fields.description: Controls the visibility of the current cell. Keep in mind that this property won't just hide the column using css. The DOM for the column will be removed. Defaults to the visible argument of the corresponding column.

attributes.name: TFootRow
attributes.description:
Renders a <tr> element and yields cell component.

<table.tfoot as |foot|>
  <foot.row as |row|>
    <row.cell>
      Footer content
    </row.cell>
  </foot.row>
</table.tfoot>

attributes.name: THead
attributes.description:
Renders a <thead> element and yields the row component.

<table.thead as |head|>
  <head.row as |row|>
    <row.column @prop="firstName" as |column|>
      First name
      {{if column.isAscSorted "(sorted asc)"}}
      {{if column.isDescSorted "(sorted desc)"}}
    </head.column>
  </head.row>
</table.thead>

fields.name: shouldDeprecate
fields.description: Used by the old head yield to indicate deprecation

attributes.name: THeadCell
attributes.description:
An component yielded from the head.row component that is used to define a cell in a row of the head of the table. Would be used for filters or any other additional information in the table head for a column

<table.thead as |head|>
  <head.row as |row|>
    <row.cell>
      <input
        class="input" type="search" placeholder="Search last name"
        value={{lastNameFilter}}
        oninput={{action (mut lastNameFilter) value="target.value"}}>
    </row.cell>
  </head.row>
</table.thead>

fields.name: visible
fields.description: Controls the visibility of the current cell. Keep in mind that this property won't just hide the column using css. The DOM for the column will be removed. Defaults to the visible argument of the corresponding column.

attributes.name: Column
attributes.description:
An important component yielded from the header or head.row component that is used to define a column of the table.

<table.header as |header|>
  <header.column @prop="firstName" as |column|>
    First name
    {{if column.isAscSorted "(sorted asc)"}}
    {{if column.isDescSorted "(sorted desc)"}}
  </header.column>
</table.header>
<table.thead as |head|>
  <head.row as |row|>
    <row.column @prop="firstName" as |column|>
      First name
      {{if column.isAscSorted "(sorted asc)"}}
      {{if column.isDescSorted "(sorted desc)"}}
    </row.column>
  </head.row>
</table.thead>

fields.name: prop
fields.description:
An important argument that Yeti Table uses to tie this column to a certain property on each row object of the original @data (or @loadFunction) that was passed in.

This is the argument that Yeti Table uses to filter and sort the data.

This argument also allows Yeti Table to keep itself up to date when the original data changes. NOTE: If this property is a nested property (one that contains periods), the table will not update when this property changes. This is due to @each only supporting one level of properties.

If you don't need sorting, filtering or automatic table unrolling (using the blockless body component), then this property is optional.

fields.name: visible
fields.description: Set to false to hide the entire column across all rows. Keep in mind that this property won't just hide the column using css. The DOM for the column will be removed. Defaults to true.

fields.name: sortable
fields.description: Used to turn off sorting clicking on this column (clicks won't toggle sorting anymore). Useful on avatar columns, for example, where a sorting order doesn't really make sense. Defaults to the <YetiTable> @sortable argument (which in turn defaults to true).

fields.name: sort
fields.description: Optionally use an asc or desc string on this argument to turn on ascending or descending sorting on this column. Useful to turn on default sortings on the table.

fields.name: sortSequence
fields.description: Use @sortSequence to customize the sequence in which the sorting order will cycle when clicking on this column header. You can either pass in a comma-separated string or an array of strings. Accepted values are 'asc', 'desc' and 'unsorted'. The default value is ['asc', 'desc'] or whatever the global table sortSequence value is.

fields.name: filterable
fields.description: Used to turn off filtering for this column. When false, Yeti Table won't look for values on this column. Defaults to true.

fields.name: filter
fields.description:
The column filter. If passed in, Yeti Table will search this column for rows that contain this string and show those rows.

The column definitions @filter argument is subtractive, meaning that it will filter out rows from the subset that passes the general @filter.

fields.name: filterFunction
fields.description:
An optional function to customize the filtering logic on this column. This function should return true or false to either include or exclude the row on the resulting set. If this function depends on a value, pass that value as the @filterUsing argument.

This function will be called with two arguments:

  • value - the current data cell to use for filtering
  • filterUsing - the value you passed in as @filterUsing

fields.name: filterUsing
fields.description: If you @filterFunction function depends on a different value (other that @filter) to show, pass it in this argument. Yeti Table uses this argument to know when to recalculate the fitlered rows.

fields.name: columnClass
fields.description: Used to add a class to all the cells in this column.

fields.name: name
fields.description: This property is a human-readable representation of the name of the column. It defaults to the trimmed textContent of the <th> element, but can be overrided by using a @name="your custom name" argument.

yields.name: column.isSorted
yields.description: `true` if column is sorted ascending or descending

yields.name: column.isAscSorted
yields.description: `true` if column is sorted ascending

yields.name: column.isDescSorted
yields.description: `true` if column is sorted descending

attributes.name: THeadRow
attributes.description:
Renders a <tr> element and yields the column and cell component.

<table.thead as |head|>
  <head.row as |row|>
    <row.column @prop="firstName" as |column|>
      First name
      {{if column.isAscSorted "(sorted asc)"}}
      {{if column.isDescSorted "(sorted desc)"}}
    </head.column>
  </head.row>
</table.thead>
